title: Grain Storage | Storage Hygiene and Structural Treatments

tasks.task: Conducting a maintenance and hygiene oversight for grain storage facilities.
subtasks: Ensuring all grain storage areas, including hopper basins and flat-bottom silos, are thoroughly cleaned of any residual grain or debris.
Removing any spilled grain around silos to prevent insect breeding; apply a thin layer of diatomaceous earth as a treatment to kill remaining pests.
Applying diatomaceous earth using a blast-back gun or leaf blower into the interior of cone-bottom silos to achieve thorough coverage.
Cleaning equipment like headers, trucks, and chaser bins to eliminate pest harborages and applying diatomaceous earth as a slurry to machinery if necessary.
Disposing of waste grain from cleaning operations through methods such as burial, burning, feeding livestock, or dispersing to discourage insect breeding.
Understanding the timing of cleaning operations, preferably during cooler months when pest activity is minimized to prevent immediate infestation post-cleaning.

Preparing grain storage facilities with diatomaceous earth treatments approximately 5-10 days before harvest to prevent pest resurgence, particularly for high-value commodities like pulses and oilseeds.
Using appropriate personal protective equipment (dust mask, gloves, goggles) when handling diatomaceous earth due to its abrasive nature and potential eye irritation.

tasks.task: Conducting annually workshops on grain storage hygiene and structural treatments.
subtasks: Presenting research and best practices on pest management during storage, including the lifecycle and breeding habits of common grain pests.
Demonstrating methods for effective cleaning of grain storage facilities and equipment, emphasizing the removal of shelter and food sources.
Explaining the application process for diatomaceous earth as a structural treatment, including precautions and considerations for different storage types.
Addressing questions from participants through a Q&A session and providing resources for further information, such as the storedgrain. com. au website and the Grain Storage Extension Team hotline.
